when.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: When did you first meet Dr Darnall?
When will the work be finished?
I don’t know when I’ll see her again.
I’ll tell you when to stop.
when.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: at or during the time that something happens
when.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Leonard was nine when his father died.
When the family came here from Russia, they were penniless.
When he was in the air force he flew Tornado jets.
when.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: after or as soon as something happens
when.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: When the meal was finished, Rachel washed up and made coffee.
I’ll phone you again when I get home.
when.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: used to mention a type of event or situation when talking about what happens on occasions of that type
when.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: When lead is added to petrol, it improves the car’s performance.
When mixed with water the powder forms a smooth paste.
He always wears glasses except when playing football.
when.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: used to show which particular time or occasion you are talking about
when.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: The best moment was when he scored the winning goal.
There are times when I hate him.
She remembered the day when Paula had first arrived.
when.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Why does she steal things when she could easily afford to buy them?
when.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: used to introduce a fact or statement that makes something seem surprising
when.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: When you consider that the airline handled 80 million passengers last year, the accident figures are really very small.
when.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: GRAMMAR: Choosing the right tense
when.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: You use the present tense with when
What are you planning to do when you leave college?
when.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: Don’t use ‘will’ in the clause after when
What are you planning to do when you will leave college?
when.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: You can also use the present perfect tense with when
What are you planning to do when your course has finished?
when.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3]: When talking about the past, you can use the past perfect tense with when
When the rain had stopped, they went outside
when.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: at or during the time that something happens
Call me when you get home.
When I got here, the place was empty.
during the time that something is happening – used to emphasize that something is continuing
I’ll make the salad while you set the table.
While we were on holiday, our house was burgled.
used in order to emphasize that something always happens when another thing happens
He visits his mother whenever he can.
You can come and talk to me whenever you have a problem.
used in order to say that one thing has or will have already happened when something else happens
By the time a child is five, he will have watched hundreds of hours of television.
